text: To answer the question of why the bees choose a hexagon, Ms. Bennet's class explored other shapes to see if they would tile a plane. They started with the following shapes and recorded their information in a chart.

Make a prediction

  • Which shapes will tile a plane?

Conduct an experiment

Equipment:

  • Several copies of the shapes

Directions (individually, with a partner, or a small group):

  • Use the copies of each shape to see if it will tile.
  • Record the following information in a table.

Digital Note: Click on the different "Coordinate Grid" tools above with the pre-made shapes. Click on the "duplicate" feature to begin tiling.
Student predictions will vary based on their past experiences.

Shape - Triangle A

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Triangle

Does the shape tile a plane? - Yes

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet -

2(90 + 65 + 25) = 360

Note: There are complementary and supplementary angles around the point where the shapes meet.

Shape - Quadrilateral B

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Quadrilateral B

Does the shape tile a plane? - Yes

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet -

Each angle of a square is 90˚.

4 (90) = 360

Shape - Quadrilateral S

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Quadrilateral S

Does the shape tile a plane? - Yes, 2 ways

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet - 35 + 145 + 180 = 360, 2(145 + 35) = 360, 4 (90) = 360

Shape - Quadrilateral K

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Quadrilateral K

Does the shape tile a plane? - Yes

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet - 2(60 + 120) = 360

Note: vertex angles formed

Shape - Hexagon D

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Hexagon D

Does the shape tile a plane? - Yes

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet - 3(120) = 360

Shape - Heptagon E

Does the shape tile a plane?

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet

Shape - Heptagon E

Does the shape tile a plane? - No, the shapes overlap or leave a big gap.

The total degrees in the angles where the shapes meet - Angles do not add to 360˚. We need about 102˚ more to complete the full turn of 360.

Analyze the data

  • Which polygons can be used to cover a flat surface without gaps or overlap? Explain why they fit tightly with no gaps around the points where they meet.

The triangle, quadrilaterals, and hexagon tile the plane.

They fit without gaps or overlaps because the shapes can be arranged so the angles total 360˚, which is a complete rotation.
